race.name: Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City
race.tagline: Half the climbing of San Diego. All the suffering. Plus miles of playground sand.

vitals.distance_options: Waffle ~127 mi, Wafer ~80 mi, Wanna ~40 mi
vitals.field_size: Hundreds of starters, deep North American pro field (Stetina, Gomez Villafañe, Roberge)
vitals.start_time: Near downtown Cedar City / Frontier Homestead
vitals.registration: Standard BWR online via belgianwaffleride.bike, Waffle $200-300 range
vitals.aid_stations: Several fully stocked. Riders report 3.5 hours at 23 mph between key stops.
vitals.cutoff_time: Multiple time checks. 2024 had route shortened due to weather.

climate.primary: High desert Utah - early spring weather roulette
climate.description: Early April at 5,600+ ft means below-freezing starts are common. 2024 had 'snowing sideways' pre-race day with freezing temps, high winds, and snow on run-in. Good years warm to 50s-60s°F.
challenges: Extreme variability: snow, freezing wind, rain possible
2024 edition: 'Don't expect a warm up as it won't get above freezing until mid-afternoon'
Cold hands and windchill at start
Dehydration risk once sun and pace pick up

terrain.surface: Fast-rolling but has 'hidden treachery.' Wide open valleys, ranch roads, farm doubletrack, and notorious 'playground type sand' sectors that wreck momentum. Steep washboarded descents after 110 miles.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: BWR brand cachet with unique playground sand sectors and weather roulette. Overall +3 for course character.

biased_opinion.summary: BWR Cedar City is what happens when you take the Waffle formula and add playground sand, mile-100 suffer-climbs, and Utah weather roulette. Half the climbing of San Diego but arguably more suffering because of where the difficulty is concentrated. The first 3.5 hours at 23 mph feel sustainable. The last 25 miles feel eternal.
biased_opinion.quote: '125 miles. 6k of climbing. 75% dirt. Starting at 5,600 ft. Technical riding and sand. Dry weather at elevation. Demoralizing.' - Rob Rides
strengths: The BWR brand: Professional organization with gravel pedigree
The surprise factor: 'Half the climbing' sounds easy until you hit the sand
The scenery: Expansive Utah valleys are stunning (when you can look up)
weaknesses: The weather: April in Utah can mean snow, freezing temps, or 60°F
The sand: Miles of playground sand destroy under-tired riders
The mile-100 combo: Sandy climb into rocky descent is brutal timing
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want a BWR that tests a different set of skills - sand navigation, late-race focus, weather adaptability - Cedar City delivers. Just bring 40mm+ tires.

final_verdict.one_liner: Half the climbing of San Diego. All the suffering. Plus miles of playground sand and a soul-crushing mile-100 combo.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you want a different BWR challenge that tests sand navigation, weather adaptability, and late-race mental fortitude. Cedar City punishes under-prepared riders more than they expect. Come with 40mm+ tires, cold-weather layers, and a pacing plan that saves matches for mile 100.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want BWR with more climbing: San Diego original. If you want Utah gravel without sand: Crusher in the Tushar. If you want desert gravel with guaranteed weather: BWR Arizona.

logistics.airport: Cedar City Regional (CDC) - limited. Las Vegas (LAS) - 2.5 hours. Salt Lake City (SLC) - 4 hours.
logistics.lodging_strategy: Cedar City is a college town (SUU) and national parks gateway. Hotels exist but book up race weekend. Secure rooms well in advance.
logistics.food: College town with solid options. Not a foodie destination but functional.
logistics.packet_pickup: Standard BWR format: expo day before with 'waffle + beer' scene and tech partner booths.
logistics.parking: Start/finish near downtown. Large parking fields with no major complaints.
logistics.camping:
Campground
- Pyramid Ridge camping

**Booking Tips:**
- Book early - limited inventory in small town
- Consider Kanarraville, Enoch

history.origin_story: Created to bring the BWR 'quadrupel' style of mixed-surface brutality to high-desert Utah. Half the climbing of San Diego but more sand and gravel to keep the 'unroad' identity intact. 2024 weather-shortened edition proved organizers will shorten the route if safety demands it.
notable_moments: 2020: Inaugural year - dry, dusty, demoralizing sand
2023: 'Most fun I've had in a gravel race in a long time' - Adam Roberge
2024: Snowing sideways pre-race, course shortened due to freezing temps and high winds
Part of the broader BWR series alongside California and Arizona editions
history.reputation: A real BWR, not watered-down. 'Slightly more approachable than San Diego' with less climbing but more sand and gravel. Same suffering, different landscape.

course_description.character: '125 miles. 6k of climbing. 75% dirt. Starting at 5,600 ft. Technical riding and sand. Dry weather at elevation. Demoralizing.' The first 3.5 hours average 23 mph. The last 25 miles average pain.

suffering_zones.label: The Fast Opening
suffering_zones.desc: First 3.5 hours at ~23 mph average. People burn matches trying to hold wheels in wind and on fast dirt, then pay later in the sand and climbs.

suffering_zones.label: Sand & Wind Sectors
suffering_zones.desc: Miles of 'playground type sand' and crosswinds cook legs. Under-tired wheels knife into sand causing crashes or walking. Source Endurance recommends at least 40mm tires.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Sand traps wreck momentum, under-tired = disaster

suffering_zones.label: The Soul Crusher
suffering_zones.desc: The mile-100 sandy climb is 'the most challenging climb of the course' - steep, sandy, when you're already cracked. Many report using every gear and still grinding. Cramps and walking common.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Steep sandy climb at altitude after 100 miles

suffering_zones.label: Rocky Washboard Descent
suffering_zones.desc: 20-minute rocky/technical section after the summit. 'A steep, washboarded descent jarring jaws and shoulders tenderized by 110 miles of mostly gravel.' Where tired riders crash or cramp.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Technical descent on exhausted legs, 5 miles from finish

course_description.signature_challenge: The mile-100 sandy climb leading straight into rocky/washboarded descending is the signature 'soul-crusher' that repeatedly appears in every race report.

prestige.explanation: First BWR outside California marks territory expansion, and when Pete Stetina shows up twice to win, you know the field respects this thing. The Quad-Tripel Crown series gives it standing in the gravel calendar. It's not Unbound, but drawing 600+ riders to Cedar City, Utah for punishment says something about brand power.

race_quality.explanation: Monuments of Cycling knows how to run events, and the 2026 course redesign removing sketchy singletrack for 'rippable unroad spiciness' shows they listen to feedback. Four feed zones for 117 miles is proper support. When weather forced a course shortening in 2024, they adapted instead of canceling—that's operational maturity.

experience.explanation: Red rock valleys, sandy sectors, and 360-degree desert views at 5,800 feet creates scenery most gravel races can't touch. The terrain 'never quite settles into comfort' which keeps you engaged for all 117 miles. Starting in 52°F and finishing in 85°F means you experience the full desert temperature swing in one day.

community.explanation: Forum discussions show equipment debates and course file sharing, but it's more transactional than tribal. The 'buy 3, get 4' Quad-Tripel Crown deal creates series followers, not necessarily Cedar City loyalists. It draws serious riders but hasn't built the cult following of some standalone events. As Alexey Vermeulen puts it: "With so much unknown surrounding the world, let alone the cycling community, it was hard to know what to expect going into Belgian Waffle Ride."

field_depth.explanation: Pete Stetina, Keegan Swenson, Sofia Gomez Villafane, and Rose Grant on the winner's list tells you the caliber. 600+ riders in the inaugural year shows it attracts numbers, not just names. Being part of the Quad-Tripel Crown means traveling pros treat it seriously, not as a training ride. Deeper field than most — comparable to Badlands. As Melisa Rollins puts it: "Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City was my first race on the dirt in 11 months. After finishing off my first pro season as an endurance gravel/mountain bike racer in 2022,..."

value.explanation: 117 miles of new terrain, four feed zones, and access to Utah's high desert for a weekend makes the entry fee work. The Quad-Tripel Crown deal adds value if you're doing multiple BWR events. Cedar City isn't Aspen-expensive, so lodging won't destroy your budget.

expenses.explanation: Cedar City keeps costs reasonable compared to resort destinations, and tiered early registration pricing helps if you plan ahead. The challenge is getting to southern Utah—it's not a hub airport situation. Factor in potential gear needs for altitude and temperature swings, but overall expenses stay manageable. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

length.explanation: 117 miles hits the sweet spot for gravel suffering—long enough to separate pretenders from contenders, short enough that mortals can finish before dark. The 66.5-mile Wafer option gives beginners an out without embarrassment. At 5,800 feet average elevation, those miles feel longer than sea level equivalents. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Melisa Rollins puts it: "Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City was my first race on the dirt in 11 months. After finishing off my first pro season as an endurance gravel/mountain bike racer in 2022,..."

technicality.explanation: The 2026 course removes 'crazy singletrack' but keeps sandy sectors and rocky jeep roads that demand skill. 60% unroad means equipment choices matter—ENVE pros switched from aero wheels to G23s for good reason. Sandy washboard sections separate Bay Area riders from desert veterans. More technical than most — comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Alexey Vermeulen puts it: "Coming off the final gravel section before the climb we were down to 6 riders. All we had left until the final showdown was 8 miles of false flat uphill with a headwind."

elevation.explanation: 5,940 feet of climbing over 117 miles isn't Leadville brutal, but it's steady work. Starting at 5,846 feet means you're already thin on oxygen before you begin climbing. The elevation profile shows consistent rolling rather than massive single climbs—death by a thousand cuts. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds. As Alexey Vermeulen puts it: "Coming off the final gravel section before the climb we were down to 6 riders. All we had left until the final showdown was 8 miles of false flat uphill with a headwind."

climate.explanation: June in Cedar City delivers 12.73 hours of sunshine, 77-86°F highs, and only 2.73 precipitation days all month—basically perfect gravel weather. 26% humidity keeps you dry but demands serious hydration strategy. When the 2024 edition got snow and high winds, it was weather, not climate—June eliminates that variable. Among the most weather-friendly events, easier than Badlands. As Weather-Related puts it: "With comfortable overnight temperatures increasing into the mid to upper 80s throughout the day and relatively humid conditions for the area, staying hydrated and avoiding cramping was on everyone's m..."

altitude.explanation: 5,846 feet starting elevation makes this the highest BWR start, and you'll feel it in your lungs combined with 26% humidity. It's not Colorado brutal, but sea level riders need acclimatization time or suffer accordingly. The thin air amplifies every effort, especially when dust kicks up. Similar altitude considerations to Grinduro.

logistics.explanation: Cedar City isn't a transportation hub—you're driving from Salt Lake or flying into smaller regional airports. The town handles 600+ riders fine, but accommodation options are limited compared to major cities. Course files going private in 2020 showed some early organizational hiccups that seem resolved.

adventure.explanation: Red rock valleys, sandy sectors, and rocky jeep roads at altitude in Utah's high desert—this is why gravel exists. The terrain 'never quite settles into comfort' across 117 miles of constantly changing surfaces. Starting cool and finishing hot under massive desert skies delivers the full Western experience most riders never see.

videos.title: My Gravel Race Bike Setup for Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City
videos.description:
The bike that got me a top 5 a BWR Cedar City. I get into tires and tire pressure, go full weight weenie, get into some components that I think are key for gravel racing and talk about some last minute changes I had to make. 

Check out my race report video from this race: https://youtu.be/Ri8mtN5O-0o

Thank you to Belgian Waffle Ride, Enve, Joe Goettl and Vegan Cyclist for the race footage! Check out their websites and channels here:
https://belgianwaffleride.bike/
https://www.enve.com/en/
https://www.youtube.com/user/ltteogeoj
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCpn6aFvwAI_hK9WuHcdvQGA

Silca tire pressure calculator: 
https://info.silca.cc/silca-professional-pressure-calculator

VeloNews 1x vs 2x:
https://www.velonews.com/gear/gear-issue-friction-differences-between-1x-and-2x-drivetrains/

Training plans are now available on Trainingpeaks: https://www.trainingpeaks.com/coach/dylanjohnsontraining#trainingplans

videos.title: BWR Cedar City 2020 Highlights On Board with Joe Goettl 9th Overall
videos.description:
Quick correction: Mile 74 title is supposed to be mile 54. 
The Canyon Belgian Waffle Ride, Cedar City 2020 was a race to remember! Epic, gnarly, increadibly. This was the most unique gravel race I have ever taken part in with everything form hero gravel, loose and sandy double tracks, a super steep and loose climb, and a legit, rocky mountain bike single track. Luckily, I had my Trek Checkpoint SL7 set up with Bontrager Gr1's 700x40c running about 40psi to take on this beast of a course. I made it through the initial carnage making the front group at mile 36. 

However, come mile 44, I fell off the lead and into no mans land until joining up with Brian McCulloch. We traded pulls from mile 52 to 110. I was just ahead of him coming off the mtb trail until cramps took over my legs and he went around me. I then ended up following the wrong arrows through town and finished just ahead of him. I talked to the results people to get it sorted out and we put me back behind him to officailly finish in 9th overall! 

Super stoked to crack the top 10 at a race like this! Huge thanks to Cedar City and Canyon Belgian Waffle Ride for the opportunity to showcase all the hard work us riders have put into training for events like these!

Bike Setup:
Bike: Trek Checkpoint SL7
Wheels: Bontrager Aeolus Pro3v's
Tires: Bontrager 700x40c Gr1's Team Issue set up tubeless @ 40psi
Computer: Wahoo Element Bolt
Peddles: Speedplay
Gearing: Sram XX1/Force Etap combo with 40 tooth up front and 10t - 50t cassette

videos.title: Gravel Racing is HARD! (Full Race Breakdown - Belgian Waffle Ride Utah)
videos.description:
This is the full race recap of my effort at the belgian waffle ride in Cedar City Utah. I walk you through the whole race, breakdown each sector, and give you my cycling commentary as the gravel race plays out.   

The belgian waffle ride has a mission to be known as the hardest one day bike races in North America, and this gravel race in Cedar City, Utah lives up to that goal. This gravel race had one of the best courses ive ever ridden. It wasn't too difficult so if you had good base fitness and bike handling skills, you felt pretty competitive for a while. 

BIKE SETUP : 
Bike - Canyon Grail
Wheels - IRC double cross 38s on Princeton carbonworks rims
Gearing - 2x 50/34 - 11/40
Road Shoes and pedals 

NUTRITION: 
(What I started with)
x2 cups of coffee
600 calories in SIS gels
900 calories in bottles
x2 30g bottles of ketones (should be illegal)  
(What I got on the road)
2 waters
4 SIS gels
1 Cliff Block

STRAVA
https://www.strava.com/activities/4208272197/analysis

Check out Dylan and his top 5 finish here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ri8mtN5O-0o

DAILY VLOG VIDEOS: 
Day 1 - https://youtu.be/4SYlO9PmVNs
Day 2 - https://youtu.be/f_8AO3wAGIQ
Day 3 - https://youtu.be/uWI7UF6inKU
Day 4 - https://youtu.be/FGH5k1SO5bk

videos.title: The TOUGHEST Course in Gravel - BWR Cedar City Race Recap 2023
videos.description:
Inside the Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City, Utah with Joe and Kendra Goettl. This was my 3rd time racing the BWR in Utah, and after two consecutive 9th's, it was great to finally get a podium with 4th Overall!  

I've Raced BWR in California, Ariznona, and Kansas, but Utah takes the front page in my book as the most technical course of all the BWR's, and of any gravel race I've competed in!

Follow Joe:
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/jgoettl2.0/?hl=en
Website: https://www.goettlmedia.com/

Strava file for this ride:

3. If you would like to make a one time cash donation, you may use the "give thanks" feature under the Video to do so. This helps us cover the costs of racing, travel, and video production, helping us provide you with higher quality content more often.

videos.title: BWR Utah 2025 - RAW HIGHLIGHTS
videos.description:
This one was extraordinarily special for Kendra and I to take the win at Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City, here in our home state of Utah! The inaugural edition of 2020 was the first big gravel race I'd taken on, and it lit the fire in me to peruse this crazy kind of racing. 2025 was our 5th year competing here and we came here on a mission. It is rare that things go according to your best possible plan, so we are going to soak this one up and appreciate the amazing day we had here! 

We can't say thank you enough to everyone who has helped out in any way to make a race like this possible for Us! And to everyone who reached out to congratulate us on this victory, we appreciate your kind words!

videos.curation_reason: Most recent race highlights from 2025 showing winning performance and course evolution over the years.

quotes.text: This year they decided to spice it up a little bit more - they added some single track, probably the most technical single track I have ridden in BWR and I've done Kansas and Cali now. This is definitely going to add a little bit of time.

The dust was so bad I could not see the front, I didn't know how far they were. When we pre-rode this, the gravel is completely different when you are doing 25-30 miles an hour versus doing 17 - we did not ride it at race pace.

key_challenges.name: tunnel pinch point
key_challenges.description: A major bottleneck where everyone gets crammed in. Creates crashes and dust visibility issues. Need to be in top 50 riders to avoid problems.

key_challenges.name: first off-road section climb
key_challenges.description: First real decisive section requiring 8 minutes 49 seconds, averaging 351 watts with final 2.5 minutes at 432 watts. Key positioning point.

key_challenges.name: single track section
key_challenges.description: Most technical single track in BWR series - very techy section that advantages mountain bikers. Added back after being removed due to complaints.

terrain_notes.text: Gravel feels completely different at race pace (25-30 mph) versus pre-riding at 17 mph - much more rough and loose at speed.
Course has sections where riders are flying and hitting rocks and holes with little to no warning.
Dust conditions are severe - riders report not being able to see the front or gauge gaps to lead groups.

gear_mentions.text: 40mm tire width recommended by race organizers as optimal, though 42mm specialized pathfinder pro worked well for the conditions.
Tire pressure: 27 psi front, 29 psi rear with tire inserts allows lower pressure for chunky gravel while preventing flats.
Wide rims (25mm internal, 32mm external) improve aerodynamics with wider 28-32mm tires and play well with gravel tires.
Tubolito tire inserts are game-changing for gravel - greatly reduce flat risk when hitting rocks and holes at high speed.

race_day_tips.text: Need to be in top 50 riders before tunnel at mile 4 to avoid major positioning problems and crashes.
No real warm-up - race goes from coasting to full gas immediately after tunnel, so legs feel like bricks early.
Pre-ride at race pace, not casual pace - terrain feels completely different at 25-30 mph vs 17 mph.
Remember to zip frame bag back up after taking nutrition - easy to lose gels on bumpy gravel sections.

additional_quotes.text: Cold start at 40 degrees requires dialed thermal gear - thermal jacket, vest, gloves essential for early race comfort.
Nutrition strategy: 7 bottles total - 400 calories, 100g carbs per bottle of scratch superfuel, plus backup gels in case support misses aid stations.

rider_intel.search_text: Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City features 127 miles with 6500 feet of elevation and significant technical challenges. The race starts cold at 40 degrees with a critical tunnel pinch point at mile 4 that creates crashes and dust visibility issues. Riders need to be in the top 50 to avoid problems. The first major climb at mile 19 is decisive, requiring 8+ minutes at high watts. A technical single track section at mile 115 advantages mountain bikers. Gravel feels much rougher at race pace (25-30 mph) than pre-riding speeds. Course has sections with rocks and holes hit at high speed with little warning. Recommended setup includes 40-42mm tires, tire inserts for flat protection, and lower pressures (27-29 psi). Race goes from no warm-up to full gas immediately, making positioning crucial early.
